Optimal Privacy Preserving for Federated Learning in Mobile Edge Computing

Hai M. Nguyen, Nam H. Chu, Diep N. Nguyen, Dinh Thai Hoang, Van-Dinh Nguyen,
Minh Hoàng Hà, Eryk Dutkiewicz, and Marwan Krunz
Hai M. Nguyen, Nam H. Chu, Diep N. Nguyen, Dinh Thai Hoang, and Eryk Dutkiewicz are with the School of Electrical and Data Engineering, University of Technology Sydney, Australia (email: hai.nguyen-2@student.uts.edu.au, namhoai.chu@student.uts.edu.au, diep.nguyen@uts.edu.au, hoang.dinh@uts.edu.au, eryk.dutkiewicz@uts.edu.au).Van-Dinh Nguyen is with the College of Engineering and Computer Science, VinUniversity, Hanoi, Vietnam (email: dinh.nv2@vinuni.edu.vn).Minh Hoàng Hà is with the ORLab, Faculty of Computer Science, Phenikaa University, Hanoi, Vietnam (email: hoang.haminh@phenikaa-uni.edu.vn).Marwan Krunz is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Arizona, USA (email: krunz@email.arizona.edu).The preliminary results of this work will be presented at the IEEE International Conference on Communications (ICC), Rome, Italy, 2023 [1].
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) with quantization and deliberately added noise over wireless networks is a promising approach to preserve user differential privacy while reducing wireless resources. Specifically, an FL learning process can be fused with quantized Binomial mechanism-based updates contributed by multiple users to reduce the communication overhead/cost and to protect the privacy of participating users. However, optimizing quantization parameters, communication resources (e.g., transmit power, bandwidth, and quantization bits), and the added noise to guarantee the differential privacy requirement and performance of the learned FL model remains an open and challenging problem. This article aims to jointly optimize the level of quantization, parameters of the Binomial mechanism, and communication resources so as to maximize the convergence rate under the constraints of the wireless network and differential privacy (DP) requirement. To that end, we first derive a novel DP budget estimation of the FL with quantization and Binomial noise that is tighter than the state-of-the-art bound. We then analyze the relationship between the convergence rate and the transmit power, the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the quantization/noise parameters and provide a theoretical bound on the convergence rate. This theoretical bound is decomposed into two components, including the variance of the global gradient and an upper bound on the quadratic bias that can be minimized by optimizing the communication resources, quantization, and added noise parameters. The resulting optimization turns out to be a Mixed-Integer Non-linear Programming (MINLP) problem. To tackle it, we first transform this MINLP problem into a new problem whose solutions are proved to be the optimal solutions of the original one. We then propose an approximate algorithm to solve the transformed problem with an arbitrary relative error guarantee. Extensive simulations show that under the same wireless resource constraints and differential privacy protection requirements, the proposed approximate algorithm achieves an accuracy close to the accuracy of the conventional FL without quantization and no added noise. The results can achieve a higher convergence rate while preserving users’ privacy.

Index Terms:
Binomial mechanism, differential privacy, federated learning, quantization, communication resources, convergence rate, approximate algorithm, wireless.

I Introduction

The rapid growth of mobile devices and services resulted in a huge amount of data for artificial intelligence (AI) based mobile applications, e.g., healthcare and e-commerce services. However, constructing a global model from big data is still challenging. First, due to privacy concerns, mobile users are not always willing to share their raw data (e.g., location, information, and travel habits/data). Second, fusing users’ data at a server may incur significant communication overhead/cost. In this context, Federated Learning (FL), among various distributed learning frameworks, has recently emerged as a potential solution to address these two challenges. Specifically, instead of requiring mobile users to share their raw data, FL only requires users to send their gradients based on their local data to a centralized server for the learning process. By doing so, not only the communication cost significantly decreases but also users’ privacy concerns are alleviated [2].

However, FL faces different challenges when deployed over wireless networks [3]. First, although only local gradients from mobile users are sent to the server, the communication cost remains a major concern for the FL over wireless networks (FLoWNs). The reason is that a mobile AI-based application may require updates/data from a large number of devices (in the order of thousands or more), thus putting significant stress on network resources [4]. Additionally, to achieve a certain accuracy level, multiple rounds of information exchange between the participating devices and the aggregating server are required. These problems are particularly more pronounced with complex deep learning models in which a local update may contain millions of parameters [5]. Second, due to its broadcast/open nature, wireless networks are vulnerable to many types of attacks, such as Man-in-the-Middle, DDoS, and Sybil, leading to privacy concerns [6]. Recent studies (e.g., [7], [8], and [9]) revealed that it is possible to retrieve the original data from the victims’ shared local gradients. This can void the privacy protection advantage of FL.

To address the above challenges, a few works have adopted a quantization technique to reduce communication costs. For example, in [10] and [11], the gradient elements are rounded to either 1 or -1. The authors in [12] presented another quantized FL framework that periodically averages the model’s parameters at the server’s side and quantizes the message-passing from edge nodes to the server. Furthermore, to improve the performance of FL (e.g., convergence rate), each node updates its local model by applying stochastic gradient descent (SGD) after a fixed number of iterations. Finally, to better scale the system, the server only updates the model with a fraction of the total nodes in each round. Similarly, the study in [13] proposed an FL with quantization constraint on the gradients. To establish a theoretical guarantee, the authors showed that the error caused by the quantization scheme is bounded by a term that decreases exponentially with the number of users. In [14], the authors proposed algorithms with periodic quantization and analyzed their convergence properties. In particular, they derived an upper bound on the learning time of various objective functions, including strongly convex and non-convex ones. In [15], the authors proposed a heterogeneous quantization approach that allows users to adapt the quantization parameters according to their communication resources. The network was partitioned into groups, and the local model user updates were divided into segments and aggregated the updates on segments. The authors demonstrated that their framework guarantees secure aggregation simultaneously in Byzantine scenarios and achieves convergence in non-Byzantine scenarios. Unlike the above works, the authors in [16] proposed a strategy to adjust the quantization levels during the training process. Through simulations on deep neural networks, they showed that their method achieves fewer communicated bits compared to a fixed quantization level policy. Interested readers are referred to [17] for a comprehensive survey on model quantization for deep neural networks.

To address privacy concerns in FL, there is a rising interest in Differential Privacy (DP), which is a scheme to share group pattern information of a dataset while securing the privacy of individuals. It uses a privacy budget parameter to measure the distinguishing probability between two datasets that differ by one individual record. The idea of DP is to add noise to private records in the dataset before aggregation. In [18], the authors proved that by adjusting the artificial noise, any privacy protection level can be satisfied. They also analyzed the optimal number of devices to maximize the convergence rate of the underlying learning process. This theoretical analysis also captures the trade-off between the privacy level and the convergence rate as well as the impact of the number of devices. To preserve user privacy and reduce the communication cost, the authors in [19] integrated FL with two-bit quantization and local DP mechanisms over an Internet of Vehicles network. The local DP mechanisms include a three-output mechanism for a small privacy budget, an optimal piecewise mechanism (PM-OPT), a suboptimal mechanism (PM-SUB), and a hybrid combining of PM-OPT and PM-SUB mechanism for a large privacy budget. In [20], the authors considered a Gaussian mechanism for adding noise to the gradients of FL. Compared to other works, this work achieves a tighter bound on the privacy budget. The authors in [21] studied the communication efficiency, privacy, and convergence trade-offs between the federated communication cost and local DP SDG algorithm. In particular, the proposed algorithm applied for the empirical risk minimization (ERM) optimization problem while guaranteeing the communication efficiency and privacy restrictions applied for the FL network. The authors leveraged the advantages of client subsampling and data subsampling as well as the shuffled model of privacy to deal with the limitation of DP. Theoretically, the proposed algorithm provides a lower bound on the ERM problem. Readers are referred to [22] for a more comprehensive survey of DP in FL.

Note that all aforementioned works do not take into account optimization of the system parameters (e.g., transmit power, bandwidth, and transmission time) and the quantization/noise factors while guaranteeing the DP of users in the underlying FL process. This problem is, in fact, very challenging since privacy-preserving methods often add noise to data or use quantization, hence significantly reducing the learning quality. For example, the authors in [2] proposed a framework that leverages quantization and Binomial mechanisms to reduce communication costs and provide DP. However, they only focused on the theoretical side and did not study the inherent factors of an FL system over wireless networks, e.g., limited bandwidth, transmit power, and transmission time. Moreover, the optimization of wireless/communication resources is often done on a short-term basis (e.g., at a packet of a frame length) while the learning convergence rate/accuracy must be optimized over a much longer time scale. Studying the impact of these system parameters on the performance of FLoWNs with regard to DP protection, learning accuracy, and convergence rate is the focus of this article. Our major contributions are as follows:

  • •

    Derive a novel differential privacy budget estimation of the FL with quantization and Binomial noise. This tighter privacy budget estimation allows us to study the convergence rate optimization problem over a larger feasible region, hence achieving a higher convergence rate compared to ones that use the known privacy budget estimation [2]. This is inline with the idea recently reported in [23] where the privacy budget can be treated as a type of resource.

  • •

    Analyze the relationship between the convergence rate and the transmit power, the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the quantization/noise parameters and provide a theoretical bound on the convergence rate. Later, it can be seen that the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the transmit power only appear on the right-hand side of a constraint which is a function that monotonically increases with respect to these parameters. Thus, we can fix two among three parameters, i.e., the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the transmit power, to optimize the other parameter.

  • •

    Decompose the bound into two components, including the variance of the global gradient and the quadratic bias introduced by the quantization/noise mechanism, that can be minimized by optimizing the transmit power, quantization, and noise-added parameters. The resulting optimization turns out to be a Mixed-Integer Non-linear Programming (MINLP) problem. To tackle it, we transform this MINLP problem into a new problem whose solutions are proved to be the optimal solutions of the original one. We then design an approximate algorithm that can solve the transformed problem with an arbitrary relative error guarantee.

  • •

    Extensive simulations show that for the same resources, the proposed approach achieves an accuracy close to that of the conventional FL without quantization and no noise added. This suggests a faster convergence rate for the proposed wireless FL framework while optimally preserving users’ privacy.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the architecture of FL with added noise and quantized gradients over Mobile Edge Computing (MEC), the theoretical analysis of the privacy budget estimation, and the bound on the convergence rate. The problem formulation, its approximate algorithm, and the complexity analysis are in Section III. The experiments and discussion of the numerical results are in Section IV. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section V.

II System Model and convergence analysis

This work considers a MEC architecture in which a Mobile Edge Server (MES) orchestrates an FL process consisting of M𝑀M mobile devices [24]. Each mobile device k𝑘k, k∈{1,…,M}𝑘1…𝑀k\in\{1,\ldots,M\}, has a private local dataset. This dataset can be created through the user’s activities captured by this device (e.g., health- or travel-related data) and hence subject to data privacy protection.

II-A Federated Learning over MEC

In general, the tasks in FL can be expressed as an optimization problem [25] of the average loss function F​(𝐰)𝐹𝐰F(\mathbf{w}):

min𝐰∈ℝd⁡{F​(𝐰)=1M​∑k=1Mfk​(𝐰)},subscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝐰1𝑀superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑀subscript𝑓𝑘𝐰\min_{\mathbf{\mathbf{w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\left\{F(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{M}\sum_{k=1}^{M}f_{k}(\mathbf{w})\right\}, (1)

where fk​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑘𝐰f_{k}(\mathbf{w}) is the loss function processed on device k∈{1,…,M}𝑘1…𝑀k\in\{1,\ldots,M\}, 𝐰∈ℝd𝐰superscriptℝ𝑑\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is the gradient vector and d𝑑d is the dimension of 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. The objective is to minimize the loss function by finding the optimal model parameter set 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. Problem (1) can be solved by the Federated Stochastic Gradient Descent (FSGD) approach [25], which continuously iterates the following steps:

  1. 1.

    Broadcast: At the beginning of iteration t𝑡t, the MES broadcasts the current model parameters 𝐰tsuperscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{t} to all M𝑀M mobile devices.

  2. 2.

    Local computation: After receiving 𝐰tsuperscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{t}, mobile device k𝑘k computes its local gradient 𝐠k​(𝐰t)=∇fk​(𝐰t)subscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t})=\nabla f_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) based on its local dataset, and then sends 𝐠k​(𝐰t)subscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) to the server.

  3. 3.

    Model update: The MES selects a subset of mobile devices 𝒦⊂{1,…,M}𝒦1…𝑀\mathcal{K}\subset\{1,\ldots,M\} to update the global gradients. As soon as it receives the updates from all mobile devices in 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K}, the MES estimates the gradient ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{t}) by aggregating the local gradients. Then, it updates the model parameters for the next iteration 𝐰t+1superscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbf{w}^{t+1} as follows:

    𝐠​(𝐰t)=1K​∑k∈𝒦𝐠k​(𝐰t),𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑘𝒦subscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{g}(\mathbf{w}^{t})=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}),

where K=|𝒦|𝐾𝒦K=|\mathcal{K}| is the number of selected devices and γ𝛾\gamma is the learning rate.

Since the expectation of the gradient 𝔼​[𝐠​(𝐰t)]=∇F​(𝐰t)𝔼delimited-[]𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{g}(\mathbf{w}^{t})]=\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{t}) [26], 𝐠​(𝐰t)𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{g}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) is an unbiased estimation of ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{t}). The process stops when the loss function converges, e.g., ‖𝐠​(𝐰t)‖2≤θsuperscriptnorm𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡2𝜃||\mathbf{g}(\mathbf{w}^{t})||^{2}\leq\theta where θ𝜃\theta is a given threshold 0≤θ≤10𝜃10\leq\theta\leq 1, or achieves a desirable accuracy. In the next section, we describe how the quantization and Binomial mechanisms can effectively lower communication costs and guarantee data privacy for the FL.

II-B Quantization and Privacy for FL over MEC

As mentioned before, to deal with data-intensive local gradients (millions of data points, as in [27]) that significantly consume the resources of mobile devices and the MES, quantization is often employed [2, 12]. Therefore, we adopt a stochastic q𝑞q-level quantization which converts the real values of the gradients into integer values with log2⁡(q)subscript2𝑞\log_{2}(q) bits [28], thus significantly reducing the communication overhead. This quantization mechanism is parameterized by the maximum value of the gradient D𝐷D and the quantization level q𝑞q.

At the beginning of the training process, the server instructs the devices of the quantization parameters D𝐷D and q𝑞q. A simple choice of D𝐷D is the maximum value of the loss function gradient [2]. Then, all devices re-scale each element gki​(𝐰t)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscript𝐰𝑡g_{k}^{i}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) of their local gradients 𝐠k​(𝐰t)subscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) to the range [−D,D]𝐷𝐷\left[-D,\ D\right] [2], where i𝑖i is the index of element gki​(𝐰t)subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡g^{i}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) of the vector 𝐠k​(𝐰t)subscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}). Specifically, similar to [2], we define V​(j)𝑉𝑗V(j) of an integer j∈[0,q−1]𝑗0𝑞1j\in[0,q-1] as follows:

V​(j)=−D+2​Dq−1​j.𝑉𝑗𝐷2𝐷𝑞1𝑗V(j)=-D+\frac{2D}{q-1}j. (2)

Thus, V​(j)𝑉𝑗V(j) is always within [−D,D]𝐷𝐷[-D,D]. Then, the quantized local gradient of gki​(𝐰t)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscript𝐰𝑡g_{k}^{i}(\mathbf{w}^{t}), denoted by Q​(gki​(𝐰t))𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscript𝐰𝑡Q(g_{k}^{i}(\mathbf{w}^{t})), is defined as follows:

Q​(gki​(𝐰t))={V​(r+1)with probability ​gki​(𝐰t)−V​(r)V​(r+1)−V​(r),V​(r)otherwise,𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscript𝐰𝑡cases𝑉𝑟1with probability superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscript𝐰𝑡𝑉𝑟𝑉𝑟1𝑉𝑟𝑉𝑟otherwiseQ(g_{k}^{i}(\mathbf{w}^{t}))=\begin{cases}V(r+1)&\text{with probability }\frac{g_{k}^{i}(\mathbf{w}^{t})-V(r)}{V(r+1)-V(r)},\\ V(r)&\text{otherwise},\end{cases}

where r∈[0,q−1]𝑟0𝑞1r\in[0,\ q-1] is an integer such that the value of gki​(𝐰t)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑖superscript𝐰𝑡g_{k}^{i}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) is within [V(r)\big{[}V(r), V(r+1))V(r+1)\big{)}. Thereby, the gradient size is significantly reduced by controlling the parameters, i.e., the quantization level q𝑞q and the maximum value of the gradient D𝐷D. It is worth noting that here we assume homogeneous users/devices where the same quantization parameters are applied to gradients of all users and all rounds. In practice, one can also use adaptive gradient quantization [29] to leverage the heterogeneity of users/devices or even the change in each updating round/iteration.

Another major challenge when employing an FL system over MEC is the leak of users’ privacy while devices share their local gradients. A potential solution to guarantee the DP for mobile devices is to add random noise to the local gradient updates [30]. As defined in [30], a randomized mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy if for two neighboring input datasets, say x𝑥x and y𝑦y, differ by up to one element, and for any output set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} we have:

Pr⁡([ℳ​(x)∈𝒮])≤eϵ​Pr⁡([ℳ​(y)∈𝒮])+δ,probabilitydelimited-[]ℳ𝑥𝒮superscript𝑒italic-ϵprobabilitydelimited-[]ℳ𝑦𝒮𝛿\Pr{\left[\mathcal{M}\left(x\right)\in\mathcal{S}\right]}\leq e^{\epsilon}\Pr{\left[\mathcal{M}\left(y\right)\in\mathcal{S}\right]}+\delta,

where ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 is a parameter that represents the privacy loss, often referred to as the differential privacy budget. The smaller the value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon is, the better privacy protection can be achieved. The given δ𝛿\delta is an upper bound on the probability of a bad event, i.e., the privacy is broken. In our work, we adopt the Binomial mechanism [2] to achieve the (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy.

Under the Binomial mechanism, the noise vector 𝐳𝐳\mathbf{z} is drawn from the Binomial distribution ℬ​(n,p)ℬ𝑛𝑝\mathcal{B}\left(n,p\right), i.e., for each coordinate i𝑖i, zi∼ℬ​(n,p)similar-tosubscript𝑧𝑖ℬ𝑛𝑝z_{i}\sim\mathcal{B}\left(n,p\right) is added to Q​(gki​(𝐰t))𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝑔𝑖𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡Q(g^{i}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t})) as [31]:

ℳ​(𝐠k​(𝐰t))=Q​(𝐠k​(𝐰t))+s​(𝐳−n​p),ℳsubscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡𝑄subscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡𝑠𝐳𝑛𝑝\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}))=Q\left(\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t})\right)+s\left(\mathbf{z}-np\right),

where n𝑛n and p𝑝p are parameters of the Binomial distribution, and s𝑠s is the noise scale, computed as in [2]:

s=2​Dq−1.𝑠2𝐷𝑞1s=\frac{2D}{q-1}. (3)

The rationale behind Eq. (4) is that the variance of the Binomial mechanism n​p​(1−p)𝑛𝑝1𝑝np(1-p) needs to exceed a lower bound to guarantee the (ϵ,δitalic-ϵ𝛿\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy requirement. This lower bound is directly proportional to the number of dimensions d𝑑d and inversely proportional to the probability of privacy broken.

The authors in [2] showed that the right-hand side of Eq. (5) is a privacy budget estimation when the condition (4) holds. Here, we derive a tighter privacy budget estimation in Theorem 1 below. Intuitively, for the same value of (q,n,p,Pk)𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘(q,n,p,P_{k}), the privacy budget estimation in (12) is smaller than the privacy budget estimation in (5) (more details are presented in Appendix A). Therefore, given a privacy budget upper bound ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon}, the proposed privacy budget estimation allows us to study the convergence rate optimization problem over a larger feasible region, compared to the known privacy budget estimation in [1] (hence potentially yielding a higher convergence rate). The significance of this tighter privacy budget estimation can be more pronounced where the privacy budget can be treated as a type of resource, as recently reported in [23].

Theorem 1 (Privacy Budget Estimation).

The proposed privacy budget estimation is tighter than the privacy budget estimation in [2], i.e., the right-hand side value of Eq. (12) is smaller than that of Eq. (5) with respect to the same system parameters’ and quantization/noise parameters’ values.

Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

Proposition 1.

Unlike the privacy budget estimation derived in [2], our privacy budget estimation in Eq. (12) satisfies the following properties that are helpful in effectively designing the approximate algorithm to maximize the convergence rate under wireless networks’ resource constraints and quantization/noise constraints in Section III-B: (i) Privacy budget estimation is symmetric with respect to the Binomial mechanism probability p𝑝p; (ii) Privacy budget estimation monotonically decreases with respect to the Binomial mechanism trial number n𝑛n; and (iii) Privacy budget estimation monotonically increases with respect to the level quantization q𝑞q.

Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

As later seen in Section III-B, thanks to the symmetric and monotonic properties of privacy budget estimation in Eq. (12), we design an effective algorithm to solve the proposed convergence rate optimization problem under network resource and DP constraints. First, due to the symmetric property, we only need to explore half of the domain set of p𝑝p, i.e., (0,1/2]012(0,1/2] or [1/2,1)121[1/2,1) instead of the whole interval (0,1)01(0,1). Second, the monotonicity of privacy budget estimation with respect to either n𝑛n or q𝑞q inspires a binary search over one of these variables to solve the problem.

After the quantization and Binomial processes, instead of sending the actual gradient as in a conventional FL, each device k𝑘k sends its quantized and added-noise ℳ​(𝐠k​(𝐰t))ℳsubscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t})) to the MES. The quantization significantly reduces the size of the gradient. In particular, the reduced size of the local quantized and noise-added gradient is d​log2⁡(q+n)𝑑subscript2𝑞𝑛d\log_{2}(q+n) bits [2]. We assume that Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiple Access (OFDMA) is employed for the uplink between mobile devices and the MES. Without losing the generality, here we assume all devices have the same bandwidth W𝑊W and transmission time T𝑇T, and the server uses a dedicated channel to broadcast global updates to all devices. It should be noted that the size of quantized and noise-added gradient must not exceed the capacity of its channel:

d​log2⁡(q+n)≤Rk​T, ​k∈𝒦,formulae-sequence𝑑subscript2𝑞𝑛subscript𝑅𝑘𝑇 𝑘𝒦d\log_{2}(q+n)\leq R_{k}T,\mbox{ }k\in\mathcal{K}, (15)

where Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} is the transmission rate of device k𝑘k given by Shannon’s equation

Rk=W​log2⁡(1+Pk​hkω0), ​k∈𝒦,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑘𝑊subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜔0 𝑘𝒦R_{k}=W\log_{2}\bigg{(}1+\frac{P_{k}h_{k}}{\omega_{0}}\bigg{)},\mbox{ }k\in\mathcal{K}, (16)

where ω0subscript𝜔0\omega_{0}, hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}, and Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} are the noise power, the channel gain, and the transmit power of device k𝑘k, respectively. Thus (15) can be re-expressed as

d​log2⁡(q+n)≤W​T​log2⁡(1+Pk​hkω0), ​k∈𝒦.formulae-sequence𝑑subscript2𝑞𝑛𝑊𝑇subscript21subscript𝑃𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜔0 𝑘𝒦d\log_{2}(q+n)\leq WT\log_{2}\bigg{(}1+\frac{P_{k}h_{k}}{\omega_{0}}\bigg{)},\mbox{ }k\in\mathcal{K}. (17)

Later, we can see that the wireless resource parameters, including the transmit power, the bandwidth, and the transmission time, only appear on the right-hand side of constraint (17). In addition, the right-hand-side function of (17) monotonically increases with respect to these three resource parameters. Hence, we can optimize one of these parameters while fixing the other two parameters at the maximum allowed values to optimize the convergence rate. In particular, here we vary the transmit power Pk∈[Pkmin,Pkmax]subscript𝑃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k}\in[P_{k}^{\min},P_{k}^{\max}] and fix the bandwidth and transmission time at W𝑊W and T𝑇T, where W𝑊W and T𝑇T are the maximum bandwidth and transmission time, respectively.

Finally, the server aggregates the received quantized and randomized gradients in a similar way to the conventional SGD:

𝐠~​(𝐰t)=1K​∑k∈𝒦ℳ​(𝐠k​(𝐰t)).~𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡1𝐾subscript𝑘𝒦ℳsubscript𝐠𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\tilde{\mathbf{g}}(\mathbf{w}^{t})=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}}\mathcal{M}\left(\mathbf{g}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t})\right). (18)

The learning process continues until it converges. In the next section, we present a convergence analysis of our proposed SLQBM-FL.

II-C Convergence Rate Analysis of SLQBM-FL

In this section, we analyze how the quantization and Binomial mechanisms affect the convergence rate of the FL system. When using the SGD to solve problem (1), it is well understood that the algorithm achieves an accuracy θ𝜃\theta after 𝒪​(1/ln⁡(θ))𝒪1𝜃\mathcal{O}(1/\ln(\theta)) iterations [32]. However, the convergence rate under the estimation of the global gradient at the server is still unknown. To derive the convergence rate of SLQBM-FL, as in [2], [26], we assume the following conditions hold:

  • •

    The loss function F​(𝐰t)𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡F(\mathbf{w}^{t}) is L𝐿L-smooth:

    ‖∇F​(𝐱)−∇F​(𝐲)‖≤L​‖𝐱−𝐲‖.norm∇𝐹𝐱∇𝐹𝐲𝐿norm𝐱𝐲||\nabla F(\mathbf{x})-\nabla F(\mathbf{y})||\leq L||\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}||.
  • •

    The gradient element of the loss function has an upper bound:

    |(∇F)j​(𝐰t)|≤G, ​j∈{1,…,d}.formulae-sequencesuperscript∇𝐹𝑗superscript𝐰𝑡𝐺 𝑗1…𝑑|(\nabla F)^{j}(\mathbf{w}^{t})|\leq G,\mbox{ }j\in\{1,\ldots,d\}.
  • •

    The gap between the values of the loss function at an initial parameter 𝐰0superscript𝐰0\mathbf{w}^{0} and at an optimal parameter 𝐰∗superscript𝐰\mathbf{w}^{*} is bounded

    F​(𝐰0)−F​(𝐰∗)≤Gf.𝐹superscript𝐰0𝐹superscript𝐰subscript𝐺𝑓F(\mathbf{w}^{0})-F(\mathbf{w}^{*})\leq G_{f}.

Following a similar approach as in [26], which shows the convergence rate of their Randomized SGD algorithm for computing an (θ,Λ)𝜃Λ(\theta,\Lambda)-solution, i.e., a point 𝐰~~𝐰\tilde{\mathbf{w}} such that Pr(||∇F(𝐰~||2≤θ)≥1−Λ\mbox{Pr}(||\nabla F(\tilde{\mathbf{w}}||^{2}\leq\theta)\geq 1-\Lambda for θ>0𝜃0\theta>0 and Λ∈(0,1)Λ01\Lambda\in(0,1), we formally state the convergence rate of SLQBM-FL in Theorem 2. Theorem 3 states the upper bounds on the factors that control this convergence rate.

Theorem 2 (Convergence Rate of SLQBM-FL).

The number of iterations performed by SLQBM-FL to achieve an (θ,Λ)𝜃Λ(\theta,\Lambda)-solution, for θ>0𝜃0\theta>0 and Λ∈(0,1)Λ01\Lambda\in(0,1), is bounded by:

𝒪​{1Λ​θ+σ2Λ2​θ2},𝒪1Λ𝜃superscript𝜎2superscriptΛ2superscript𝜃2\mathcal{O}\left\{\frac{1}{\Lambda\theta}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\Lambda^{2}\theta^{2}}\right\},

where σ2=U+Bsuperscript𝜎2𝑈𝐵\sigma^{2}=U+B with U𝑈U being the variance of the global gradient, and B𝐵B being the quadratic bias introduced by ℳℳ\mathcal{M}:

B𝐵\displaystyle B =max1≤t≤T⁡𝔼ℳ​[‖𝐠​(𝐰t)−𝐠~​(𝐰t)‖2].absentsubscript1𝑡𝑇subscript𝔼ℳdelimited-[]superscriptnorm𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡~𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle=\max_{1\leq t\leq T}\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{M}}\left[\|\mathbf{g}(\mathbf{w}^{t})-\tilde{\mathbf{g}}(\mathbf{w}^{t})\|^{2}\right]. (20)
Proof.

See Appendix C. ∎

Note that the authors of [2] parameterized the convergence rate through the factor σ′superscript𝜎′\sigma^{\prime}:

From Theorem 2, the convergence rate of SLQBM-FL is controlled by σ𝜎\sigma. Since σ2=2​U+2​Bsuperscript𝜎22𝑈2𝐵\sigma^{2}=2U+2B, reducing U𝑈U and B𝐵B will speed up the learning process. Theorem 3 and its following observations suggest that U𝑈U is insignificant in comparison to B𝐵B. We therefore only need to minimize B𝐵B to practically improve the convergence rate. First, from (21), we observe that when K𝐾K is close to M𝑀M, U𝑈U is very marginal or even equal to zero when K=M𝐾𝑀K=M. Second, for M>>Kmuch-greater-than𝑀𝐾M>>K (that is often the case in practice), the inequality (23)111Theoretically, the gradients of the loss function gkj​(⋅)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑘𝑗⋅g_{k}^{j}(\cdot) are aggregated to update the model, and therefore not independent. However, in our case, we quantize and add random noise to each gradient element. Furthermore, in the FL framework where K𝐾K devices are chosen randomly and M>>Kmuch-greater-than𝑀𝐾M>>K, the correlation between ∇fkj​(𝐰t)∇subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑗𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f^{j}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) and ∇fk′j​(𝐰t)∇subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑗superscript𝑘′superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f^{j}_{k^{\prime}}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) is small in comparison to G𝐺G, for k≠k′𝑘superscript𝑘′k\neq k^{\prime}. Thus, we can practically assume that the gradient elements ∇fkj​(𝐰t)∇subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑗𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f^{j}_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) are i.i.d. also suggests that U𝑈U tends to zero for a large number of devices M𝑀M. From (22), we found that n​p​(1−p)>>(q−1)2much-greater-than𝑛𝑝1𝑝superscript𝑞12np(1-p)>>(q-1)^{2}, we thus have B>>Umuch-greater-than𝐵𝑈B>>U. Third, we observe from (22) that the ratio of the upper bound and the lower bound of B𝐵B is approximately 1 as n​p​(1−p)𝑛𝑝1𝑝np(1-p) is large. Therefore, we can optimize the upper bound of B𝐵B which is a function of the wireless resources, quantization and noise-added parameters222Although, the wireless resource parameters, i.e., the bandwidth, the transmit power, and the transmission time do not appear in the formula (22), they implicitly impact on B𝐵B through constraints, e.g., (4). to improve the learning rate.

III Problem formulation and solutions

As analyzed in the previous section, to maximize the convergence rate of SLQBM-FL under the constraints on the network resources and (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy protection, we can minimize the upper bound on B𝐵B in Eq. (22) by jointly optimizing the transmit power, the quantization level, and the parameters of Binomial mechanism. The optimization problem is formally stated as follows:

(Φ1):minq,n,p,Pkφ​(q,n,p,Pk),:subscriptΦ1𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘min𝜑𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘(\Phi_{1}):\enspace\underset{q,n,p,P_{k}}{\mathrm{min}}\quad\varphi(q,n,p,P_{k}),\\ (24)
s.t. (​4​),(​17​)italic-(4italic-)italic-(17italic-)\displaystyle\quad\eqref{eq:DP_cons},\ \eqref{eq:channel_cap_cons}
ϵ≤ϵ¯,italic-ϵ¯italic-ϵ\displaystyle\quad\epsilon\leq\bar{\epsilon}, (25)
Pkm​i​n≤Pksubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑚𝑖𝑛𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘\displaystyle\quad P^{min}_{k}\leq P_{k} ≤Pkm​a​x, ​k∈𝒦,formulae-sequenceabsentsubscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑘 𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\leq P^{max}_{k},\mbox{ }k\in\mathcal{K}, (26)
q∈𝒬, ​n∈𝒩,formulae-sequence𝑞𝒬 𝑛𝒩\displaystyle\quad q\in\mathcal{Q},\mbox{ }n\in\mathcal{N}, (27)
p∈(0,1),𝑝01\displaystyle\quad p\in(0,1), (28)

where we denote the domain sets of the level quantization parameter q𝑞q and the noise parameter n𝑛n as 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} and 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}, respectively. The domain sets 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} and the objective function are defined as follows:

𝒬={2,…,⌊(1+mink∈𝒦⁡Pkmax​hk/ω0)T​W/d⌋−2},𝒬2…superscript1subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜔0𝑇𝑊𝑑2\mathcal{Q}=\{2,\ldots,\lfloor(1+\min_{k\in\mathcal{K}}P_{k}^{\max}h_{k}/\omega_{0})^{TW/d}\rfloor-2\}, (29)

φ​(q,n,p,Pk)=1+n​p​(1−p)(q−1)2.𝜑𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘1𝑛𝑝1𝑝superscript𝑞12\displaystyle\varphi(q,n,p,P_{k})=\frac{1+np(1-p)}{(q-1)^{2}}. (31)

Since the data dimension d𝑑d, the gradient’s upper bound G𝐺G, and the number of devices K𝐾K are often known in advance [2], we omit 4​d​G2/K4𝑑superscript𝐺2𝐾4dG^{2}/K from the upper bound on B𝐵B in (22) to obtain the objective function of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) as in Eq. (31). The constraints of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) represent the differential privacy and system implementation requirements. In particular, constraint (4) guarantees that the framework follows the (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential privacy. Constraints (17) and (26) capture the channel capacity and transmit power constraints of each device, respectively. Constraint (25) ensures that the differential privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, expressed in Eq. (12), does not exceed a given upper bound ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon}. Finally, constraints (27) and (28) describe the domain set of the quantization level q𝑞q and Binomial mechanism parameters n𝑛n and p𝑝p. The upper bound ⌊(1+mink∈𝒦⁡Pkmax​hk/ω0)T​W/d⌋−2superscript1subscript𝑘𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝜔0𝑇𝑊𝑑2\lfloor(1+\min_{k\in\mathcal{K}}P_{k}^{\max}h_{k}/\omega_{0})^{TW/d}\rfloor-2 of q𝑞q and n𝑛n in Eqs. (29) and (30) is derived from the constraint (17).

Finally, we discuss the relationship between the system parameters, e.g., the maximum transmit power, the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the optimal objective value of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}). Remark 1 summarizes the relationship between the optimal objective value of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) and these parameters.

Remark 1 (Dependence of Optimal Solution Value on the System Parameters).

If the maximum transmit power Pkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k}^{\max} or the maximum transmission time T𝑇T or the bandwidth W𝑊W increases, the optimal objective function of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) will not increase.

III-A Problem Transformation

The proposed problem (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) is an MINLP problem. In this section, we transform (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) to a new problem (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) whose optimal solution set can be used to derive the optimal solution set of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}). The advantage of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) over (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) is that it can be effectively solved by approximate solutions with arbitrarily small errors. Specifically, applying transformations on the constraints of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}), we obtain a new MINLP problem denoted as (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}).

(Φ2):minq,n,p,Pkφ​(q,n,p,Pk),:subscriptΦ2𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘min𝜑𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘(\Phi_{2}):\enspace\underset{q,n,p,P_{k}}{\mathrm{min}}\quad\varphi(q,n,p,P_{k}),\\ (32)
s.t. (​27​),(​28​),italic-(27italic-)italic-(28italic-)\displaystyle\ \eqref{eq:domain_set_q_n},\ \eqref{eq:domain_set_p},
n=max⁡{⌈max⁡{23​ln⁡10​dδ,2​(q+1)}K​p​(1−p)⌉,n1},𝑛2310𝑑𝛿2𝑞1𝐾𝑝1𝑝subscript𝑛1\displaystyle n=\max\Big{\{}\Big{\lceil}\frac{\max\{23\ln\frac{10d}{\delta},2(q+1)\}}{Kp(1-p)}\Big{\rceil},n_{1}\Big{\}}, (33)
Pk=min⁡{Pkmax,max⁡{Pkmin,ω0​[(q+n)dT​W−1]hk}},subscript𝑃𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘subscript𝜔0delimited-[]superscript𝑞𝑛𝑑𝑇𝑊1subscriptℎ𝑘\displaystyle P_{k}=\min\Big{\{}P^{\max}_{k},\max\Big{\{}P_{k}^{\min},\frac{\omega_{0}[(q+n)^{\frac{d}{TW}}-1]}{h_{k}}\Big{\}}\Big{\}},
k∈𝒦,𝑘𝒦\displaystyle\hskip 100.0ptk\in\mathcal{K}, (34)

where φ​(q,n,p,Pk)𝜑𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘\varphi(q,n,p,P_{k}) is defined in (31), and in the constraint (33) n1subscript𝑛1n_{1} is explained in detail as follows.

In particular, to derive (33), we first observe that the inequality (4) is equivalent to the following inequality

n≥⌈max⁡{23​ln⁡10​dδ, 2​(q+1)}K​p​(1−p)⌉.𝑛2310𝑑𝛿2𝑞1𝐾𝑝1𝑝n\geq\left\lceil\frac{\max\big{\{}23\ln\frac{10d}{\delta},\ 2(q+1)\big{\}}}{Kp(1-p)}\right\rceil. (35)

Second, the privacy budget ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon monotonically decreases with respect to n𝑛n (more details are provided in Appendix E); therefore, given the quantization level q𝑞q and Binomial mechanism parameter p𝑝p, there exists an integer n1subscript𝑛1n_{1} such that ϵ​(n)≤ϵ¯italic-ϵ𝑛¯italic-ϵ\epsilon(n)\leq\bar{\epsilon} if and only if n≥n1𝑛subscript𝑛1n\geq n_{1}. n1subscript𝑛1n_{1} is derived by applying the binary search with respect to n∈𝒩𝑛𝒩n\in\mathcal{N}. Combining these two facts with the monotonic property of the objective function with respect to n𝑛n, we obtain the constraint (33). The constraint (34) follows from the fact that the smaller the transmit power is, the better the power efficiency can be achieved. Theorem 4 formally states the relationship between the problem (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) and the problem (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}).

Theorem 4 (Solutions of Problems (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) and (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2})).

(i): If (q∗,n∗,p∗,Pk∗)superscript𝑞superscript𝑛superscript𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘(q^{*},n^{*},p^{*},P_{k}^{*}) is an optimal solution of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}), (q∗,n∗,p∗,Pk∗)superscript𝑞superscript𝑛superscript𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑘(q^{*},n^{*},p^{*},P^{*}_{k}) is also an optimal solution of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}). (ii): If (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) is infeasible, (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) is also infeasible. (iii): The set {(q∗,n∗,p∗,Pk)|Pk∗≤Pk≤Pkmax​ and ​(q∗,n∗,p∗,Pk∗)​ is an optimal solution of ​(Φ2)}conditional-setsuperscript𝑞superscript𝑛superscript𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘 and superscript𝑞superscript𝑛superscript𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘 is an optimal solution of subscriptΦ2\{(q^{*},n^{*},p^{*},P_{k})|~{}P_{k}^{*}\leq P_{k}\leq P_{k}^{\max}\mbox{ and }(q^{*},n^{*},p^{*},P_{k}^{*})\mbox{ is an optimal solution of }(\Phi_{2})\} is the optimal solution set of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}), i.e., we can derive all the optimal solutions of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) from optimal solutions of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}).

Proof.

See Appendix E. ∎

Theorem 4 shows that we can obtain the solution of (Φ1)subscriptΦ1(\Phi_{1}) by solving (Φ2)subscriptΦ2(\Phi_{2}). An advantage of (Φ2)subscriptΦ2(\Phi_{2}) in comparison with (Φ1)subscriptΦ1(\Phi_{1}) is that we only need to consider the variables p𝑝p and q𝑞q, and easily derive the values of Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} and n𝑛n based on the Eqs. (33) and (34). In the next section, we propose an approximate algorithm to solve (Φ2)subscriptΦ2(\Phi_{2}) that guarantees arbitrary small errors and works effectively in practice.

III-B Approximate Algorithm

In this section, we design Algorithm 2 to solve the problem (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}). The main idea is to perform a search on the Cartesian product set 𝒬×𝒫𝒬𝒫\mathcal{Q}\times\mathcal{P}, where 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} and 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} are the finite subsets of the domain sets of the quantization level q𝑞q and the Binomial mechanism parameter p𝑝p, respectively. The quantization level domain set 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is defined as 𝒬={2,…,q¯}𝒬2…¯𝑞\mathcal{Q}=\{2,\ldots,\bar{q}\}, where the level quantization upper bound q¯¯𝑞\bar{q} is defined by Lemma 2. The Binomial mechanism parameter domain set 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} is defined as 𝒫=𝒫λ∪{1/2}𝒫subscript𝒫𝜆12\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{\lambda}\cup\{1/2\}. Set 𝒫λsubscript𝒫𝜆\mathcal{P}_{\lambda} contains all elements that are larger than 1/2 and smaller than 1 of the arithmetic progression sequence i​λ𝑖𝜆i\lambda for some λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 and i∈ℕ+𝑖superscriptℕi\in\mathbb{N}^{+}. The restriction p≥1/2𝑝12p\geq 1/2 is explained by Lemma 1.

Lemma 1 (Symmetric Property of the Feasible Region of Problem (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) with Symmetry Point p=1/2𝑝12p=1/2).

If (q~,n~,p~,P~k)~𝑞~𝑛~𝑝subscript~𝑃𝑘(\tilde{q},\tilde{n},\tilde{p},\tilde{P}_{k}) is a feasible solution of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) then (q~,n~,1−p~,P~k)~𝑞~𝑛1~𝑝subscript~𝑃𝑘(\tilde{q},\tilde{n},1-\tilde{p},\tilde{P}_{k}) is also a feasible solution of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) with the same objective value.

Proof.

See Appendix F. ∎

In Algorithm 2, each iteration of the FOR loop (lines 2-11) corresponds to a particular pair (q,p)∈𝒬×𝒫𝑞𝑝𝒬𝒫(q,p)\in\mathcal{Q}\times\mathcal{P}. First, on the line 3, we compute n1subscript𝑛1n_{1}. Second, on line 4 we compute the value n𝑛n by Eq. (33). Third, on line 5 we check (17). If it satisfies, we compute the objective value φ𝜑\varphi of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) and update the solution (lines 7-9). Finally, the transmit power is computed (lines 12-14).

Lemma 1 shows that instead of considering p∈(0,1)𝑝01p\in(0,1), we only need to study p∈[1/2,1)𝑝121p\in[1/2,1). Thus, this lemma helps to speed up Algorithm 2. Likewise, in Lemma 2, we present an upper bound for the quantization level q𝑞q that also helps to reduce the running time of Algorithm 2.

Lemma 2 (Upper Bound on the Quantization Level q𝑞q for p≥1/2𝑝12p\geq 1/2).

For each privacy budget upper bound ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon}, there exists an integer q¯¯𝑞\bar{q} such that to satisfy the privacy budget condition ϵ<ϵ¯italic-ϵ¯italic-ϵ\epsilon<\bar{\epsilon}, the level quantization q𝑞q must not exceed q¯¯𝑞\bar{q} for every p≥1/2𝑝12p\geq 1/2. The upper bound q¯¯𝑞\bar{q} can be computed by solving the equation g​(q)=ϵ¯𝑔𝑞¯italic-ϵg(q)=\bar{\epsilon}, where g​(p)𝑔𝑝g(p) defined by Eq. (56) is a monotonically increasing function with respect to q𝑞q.

Proof.

See Appendix G. ∎

In the next section, we prove that we can control the relative error of Algorithm 2. Furthermore, in Section III-D, we analyze the complexity of this algorithm.

III-C Relative Error of Algorithm 2

Theorem 5 below states that Algorithm 2 can generate a ρ𝜌\rho-relative error solution (q~,n~,p~,P~k~𝑞~𝑛~𝑝subscript~𝑃𝑘\tilde{q},\tilde{n},\tilde{p},\tilde{P}_{k}), i.e., φ​(q~,n~,p~,P~k)/φ∗<1+ρ𝜑~𝑞~𝑛~𝑝subscript~𝑃𝑘superscript𝜑1𝜌\varphi(\tilde{q},\tilde{n},\tilde{p},\tilde{P}_{k})/\varphi^{*}<1+\rho, where φ∗superscript𝜑\varphi^{*} is the optimal objective value of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}). In addition, Theorem 6 gives an approach to compute the value λ𝜆\lambda to guarantee an arbitrary ρ𝜌\rho when η=min⁡{23​ln⁡(10​d/δ),6}/(K​n¯𝒩)<0.25𝜂2310𝑑𝛿6𝐾subscript¯𝑛𝒩0.25\eta=\min\{23\ln(10d/\delta),6\}/(K\bar{n}_{\mathcal{N}})<0.25, where 6 is the smallest value of 2​(q+1)2𝑞12(q+1), which appears in inequality (4), and n¯𝒩subscript¯𝑛𝒩\bar{n}_{\mathcal{N}} is the maximum value of Binomial parameter set 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N}. Since η≤6/(K​n¯𝒩)𝜂6𝐾subscript¯𝑛𝒩\eta\leq 6/(K\bar{n}_{\mathcal{N}}), the condition η<0.25𝜂0.25\eta<0.25 holds if the following condition holds:

K≥12​ or ​n¯𝒩≥12.𝐾12 or subscript¯𝑛𝒩12K\geq 12\mbox{ or }\bar{n}_{\mathcal{N}}\geq 12. (36)

In other words, if the condition (36) holds, the relative error is bounded as shown in Theorem 6: ρ<μ​λ𝜌𝜇𝜆\rho<\mu\lambda, where μ=2/(1−1−4​η)𝜇2114𝜂\mu=2/\big{(}1-\sqrt{1-4\eta}\big{)}. Since in practice, the FLoWNs often contain thousands of devices [2], the condition K≥13𝐾13K\geq 13 is likely to occur. Even in the case K<13𝐾13K<13, we can add 13 to 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} without losing the generality to guarantee that the condition (36) always holds.

Theorem 5 (Relative Error Property of Solution obtained by Algorithm 2).

For arbitrary ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0, there exists a positive λ¯¯𝜆\bar{\lambda} such that for every λ<λ¯𝜆¯𝜆\lambda<\bar{\lambda}, Algorithm 2 with 𝒫λ={i​λ|i∈ℕ+,1/2<i​λ<1}subscript𝒫𝜆conditional-set𝑖𝜆formulae-sequence𝑖superscriptℕ12𝑖𝜆1\mathcal{P}_{\lambda}=\{i\lambda|i\in\mathbb{N}^{+},1/2<i\lambda<1\} returns a feasible solution (q~,n~,p~,P~k)~𝑞~𝑛~𝑝subscript~𝑃𝑘(\tilde{q},\tilde{n},\tilde{p},\tilde{P}_{k}) satisfying ρ𝜌\rho-relative error for (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}), and this solution is also a ρ𝜌\rho-relative error solution of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}), i.e.:

φ​(q~,n~,p~,P~k)φ∗<1+ρ.𝜑~𝑞~𝑛~𝑝subscript~𝑃𝑘superscript𝜑1𝜌\frac{\varphi(\tilde{q},\tilde{n},\tilde{p},\tilde{P}_{k})}{\varphi^{*}}<1+\rho.
Proof.

See Appendix H. ∎

Theorem 6 (Relative Error’s Upper Bound on Solution Returned by Algorithm 2).

For λ<λ¯𝜆¯𝜆\lambda<\bar{\lambda}, where λ¯¯𝜆\bar{\lambda} is defined in Theorem 5, and η<0.25𝜂0.25\eta<0.25, the relative error ρ𝜌\rho of the solution returned by Algorithm 2 satisfying: ρ<μ​λ𝜌𝜇𝜆\rho<\mu\lambda, where μ=2/(1−1−4​η)𝜇2114𝜂\mu=2/(1-\sqrt{1-4\eta}).

Proof.

See Appendix I. ∎

Applying Theorem 6, we can estimate λ𝜆\lambda to guarantee that Algorithm 2 returns a feasible solution satisfying a given relative error ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0. In general, we select value λ<ρ/μ𝜆𝜌𝜇\lambda<\rho/\mu. Specifically, for the case η<<1much-less-than𝜂1\eta<<1, since μ=2/(1−1−4​η)=2​(1+1−4​η)/(4​η)≈1/η𝜇2114𝜂2114𝜂4𝜂1𝜂\mu=2/(1-\sqrt{1-4\eta})=2(1+\sqrt{1-4\eta})/(4\eta)\approx 1/\eta, we can select λ𝜆\lambda such that λ<ρ​η𝜆𝜌𝜂\lambda<\rho\eta.

III-D Complexity of Algorithm 2

In Algorithm 1, we implement a binary search with respect to the Binomial mechanism parameter n𝑛n. Therefore, the complexity of Algorithm 1 is 𝒪​(log2⁡|𝒩|)𝒪subscript2𝒩\mathcal{O}(\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|), where 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} is the domain set of n𝑛n. In practice, we assign 𝒩𝒩\mathcal{N} to the set of all integers between 2 and 2bsuperscript2𝑏2^{b}, where b𝑏b is the maximum number of bits of each gradient element, e.g., 8 or 16 [2]. In such context, the complexity of Algorithm 1 is 𝒪​(b)𝒪𝑏\mathcal{O}(b).

Considering Algorithm 2, the FOR loop (lines 2-11) repeats for |𝒬|​|𝒫|𝒬𝒫|\mathcal{Q}||\mathcal{P}| times. Inside this loop, the most significant computation is the binary search (line 3) whose complexity is 𝒪​(log2⁡|𝒩|)𝒪subscript2𝒩\mathcal{O}(\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|). Therefore, the complexity of Algorithm 2 is 𝒪​(|𝒬|​|𝒫|​log2⁡|𝒩|)𝒪𝒬𝒫subscript2𝒩\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{Q}||\mathcal{P}|\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|). Since |𝒫|=𝒫λ∪{1/2}≤1/(2​λ)+1𝒫subscript𝒫𝜆1212𝜆1|\mathcal{P}|=\mathcal{P}_{\lambda}\cup\{1/2\}\leq 1/(2\lambda)+1, the complexity of Algorithm 2 is 𝒪​(|𝒬|​log2⁡|𝒩|/λ)𝒪𝒬subscript2𝒩𝜆\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{Q}|\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|/\lambda), which is pseudo-polynomial. Recall that to satisfy the ρ𝜌\rho-relative error the following condition holds: λ<ρ/μ𝜆𝜌𝜇\lambda<\rho/\mu. Since μ𝜇\mu is a constant, to achieve ρ𝜌\rho-relative error, the complexity of Algorithm 2 is 𝒪​(|𝒬|​log2⁡|𝒩|/ρ)𝒪𝒬subscript2𝒩𝜌\mathcal{O}(|\mathcal{Q}|\log_{2}|\mathcal{N}|/\rho).

IV Experiment results

IV-A Parameters Settings

To perform the experiments, we consider a network with 1 million mobile devices, i.e., M=106𝑀superscript106M=10^{6}, and in general, set the number of selected mobile devices to update the global gradient K=1000𝐾1000K=1000. In a special case that studies the impact of the number of selected devices K𝐾K on the convergence rate, we vary the value of K𝐾K between 101010, 102superscript10210^{2}, 103superscript10310^{3}, and 104superscript10410^{4}. We set the square of channel gains hk2superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘2h_{k}^{2} following the exponential distribution with the mean g0​(D0/Dk)4subscript𝑔0superscriptsubscript𝐷0subscript𝐷𝑘4g_{0}(D_{0}/D_{k})^{4}, where g0=−40subscript𝑔040g_{0}=-40 dB, the reference distance D0=1subscript𝐷01D_{0}=1 m, and distance Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} between the mobile edge server and device k𝑘k is randomly sampled from [Dmin,Dmax]subscript𝐷subscript𝐷[D_{\min},D_{\max}] with Dmin=2subscript𝐷2D_{\min}=2 m and Dmax=200subscript𝐷200D_{\max}=200 [33]. For each device, the bandwidth is set to 900 MHz [34]. The transmit power is restricted as Pk∈{1,…,20}subscript𝑃𝑘1…20P_{k}\in\{1,\ldots,20\} dBm, for k∈{1,…,M}𝑘1…𝑀k\in\{1,\ldots,M\}, similar to [33]. We implement a three-layer neural network with 785 nodes in the input layer, 60 hidden nodes, and 10 nodes in the output layer using the ADAM training algorithm. We also use the ReLU activate function and use the infinite MNIST dataset as input, similar to [2]. The simulated framework is built with Python and NumPy. For the differential privacy security, we set δ=10−10𝛿superscript1010\delta=10^{-10} [2]. In addition, we restrict the number of allowed transmit bits per parameter to 16 bits, similar to [2].

IV-B Privacy evaluation

We first aim to study the efficiency of the proposed privacy budget estimation (12) in comparison with the privacy budget estimation (5) presented in [2]. We compute the solutions (q,n,p,Pk)𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘(q,n,p,P_{k}) with respect to the privacy budget upper bound ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon} which is varied from 1 to 10 using the proposed privacy budget estimation in Eq. (12). We then compute the privacy budget estimation over these solutions applying Eq. (5). The results in Fig. 2 show that our proposed privacy budget estimation gives a tighter estimation than the proposed one in [2], i.e., the right-hand side of Eq. (12) is smaller than the right-hand side of Eq. (5) with respect to the same system and quantization/noise parameters.

We then investigate the impact of the maximum privacy budget on the learning time of SLQBM-FL. Recall that the objective of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) is to maximize the SLQBM-FL learning rate. Thus, the lower value of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2})’s objective function is, the lower the learning time of SLQBM-FL is. We study the scenarios corresponding to the privacy budget ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon} varying from 1 to 10 [2]. Fig. 3 shows the objective function value φ​(q,n,p,Pk)𝜑𝑞𝑛𝑝subscript𝑃𝑘\varphi(q,n,p,P_{k}) of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) of the solution returned by Algorithm 2 when the upper bound on differential privacy budget ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon} varies from 1 to 10. It is clear that as ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon} increases, i.e., the privacy requirement gets less restricted, the objective function value gets decreased, meaning that the convergence rate increases. This is stemmed from the fact that the higher the value of ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon} is, the lower the amount of noise added to gradients by the Binomial mechanism is. Consequently, the learning time (indicated via our objective function) reduces due to less noise as ϵ¯¯italic-ϵ\bar{\epsilon} increases from 1 to 10.

IV-C Convergence rate analysis

Now, we investigate the dependence of the convergence rate on the device number K𝐾K. Theoretically, the upper bound B𝐵B of the quadratic bias introduced by mechanism ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, which defines the objective value of both (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) and (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}), is inversely proportional to K𝐾K. Therefore, the larger the value of K𝐾K, the higher the convergence rate is. Fig. 4 shows the accuracy curves of the solutions returned by Algorithm 2 corresponding to different values of the device number K=𝐾absentK= 101010, 102superscript10210^{2}, 103superscript10310^{3}, and 104superscript10410^{4}. It is clear that as K𝐾K increases the convergence rate increases since the aggregated noise reduces as the number of aggregated devices increases.

We then investigate the convergence of SLQBM-FL with the parameters of quantization and Binomial mechanisms obtained by our proposed Algorithm 2, namely Prop. sol.. In this experiment, we select four baseline approaches, i.e., the conventional FL that operates without quantization and differential privacy mechanisms, and three feasible solutions to the problem (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}). In particular, the feasible solutions returned by Algorithm 2 are clustered into 3 groups based on their objective function value. We then select the solution with the smallest objective value of each group. As shown in Fig. 5, even though the quantization and Binomial mechanism introduce noise to data, our proposed solution still achieves an accuracy that is close to that of the conventional FL after 250025002500 global update rounds. We also observe that the accuracy curve of Sol. 1 gets close to the accuracy curve of our proposed solution. The reason is that the objective value of Sol. 1 is the second smallest and is close to the objective value of our proposed solution. Thus, it demonstrates the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm in optimizing the system parameters, i.e., transmit power and the quantization/noise parameters for the SLQBM-FL.

IV-D System efficiency

Next, we investigate the dependence of the objective function of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) on the system parameters, including the maximum transmit power Pkmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k}^{\max}, the bandwidth W𝑊W, and the transmission time T𝑇T, as shown in Figs. 6, 7, and 8, respectively. Generally, as these system parameters increase, the domain sets of these parameters get expanded. Thus, the objective function value of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) decreases or at least does not increase. In other words, the convergence rate gets improved as increasing these communication resources.

To study the communication cost-effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, we compute the communication costs in Giga bits (Gbs) as the product of 4 integers including the number of training rounds, the number of selected mobile devices, i.e., K=1000𝐾1000K=1000, the number of dimensions d𝑑d, and the number of bits per quantized gradient element. In particular, the number of training rounds counts the number of global update rounds until the accuracy achieves 88%. The reason behind the value 88% is that this value is the accuracy threshold of the most feasible solutions in empirical. The communication costs of the proposed Algorithm 2 and four baseline approaches are presented in a bar chart in Fig. 9. The result of Sol. 3 is not presented here as its accuracy cannot achieve the threshold of 88%. It is clear that the proposed algorithm solution’s communication cost is close to conventional FL and significantly lower than those of the other feasible solutions. In addition, the communication cost of the proposed algorithm is also lower than that of the FL with no quantization but with added noise, showing the effectiveness of the quantization mechanism.

Finally, we investigate the level quantization upper bound q¯¯𝑞\bar{q} derived from Lemma 2. Figure 10 shows this upper bound when varying the maximum transmit power. First, it shows that as the transmit power increases, the level quantization upper bound also increases. Second, it shows the efficiency of Lemma 2 to reduce the search range of level quantization q𝑞q. In particular, when we set the number of bits per gradient element not to exceed 16 [2], instead of searching the range from 222 to 216superscript2162^{16}, we only need to consider the range from 222 to q¯¯𝑞\bar{q}, which is less than 216superscript2162^{16} by a factor of 100, as shown in Fig. 10.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we first derived a tighter than the state-of-the-art differential privacy budget estimation for Federated learning over mobile edge networks with quantized gradients and added noise (to protect mobile users’ privacy). By analyzing the relationship between the convergence rate and the system parameters, i.e., the transmit power, the bandwidth, the transmission time, and the quantization/noise parameters, we provided a theoretical bound on the convergence rate. This bound was decomposed into two components, including the variance of the global gradient and the quadratic bias introduced by the quantization/noise mechanism. We then analyzed the theoretical and practical reasons to improve the convergence rate by optimizing the upper bound of the quadratic bias. We then jointly optimized the level of quantization, the Binomial mechanism’s parameters, and the transmit power. The resulting problem is an MINLP. To tackle it, we transformed the problem into the new one whose optimal solutions are proved to be optimal solutions of the original one. We then designed an effective algorithm that can approximately solve the new problem with an arbitrary relative error. Extensive simulations showed with mostly the same wireless resources the proposed approach achieves an accuracy that is close to that of the conventional FL without quantization and without added noise while achieving the required DP protection. This suggested the faster convergence rate of the proposed wireless FL framework while optimally preserving users’ privacy.

Appendix A Proof of Theorem 1

To prove Theorem 1, we need the following lemmas.

Lemma 3.

For any z≥−1/3𝑧13z\geq-1/3 the following inequality holds

|ln⁡((1+z))−z|≤α​z2,1𝑧𝑧𝛼superscript𝑧2|\ln{(1+z)}-z|\leq\alpha z^{2},

where α=−3−9​ln⁡((2/3))𝛼3923\alpha=-3-9\ln{\left(2/3\right)}.

If B=0𝐵0B=0, 𝐠~​(𝐰t)~𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡\tilde{\mathbf{g}}(\mathbf{w}^{t}) is an unbiased estimation of ∇F​(𝐰t)∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{t}) and the SLQBM-FL becomes unbiased with ‖𝐠​(𝐰t)−∇F​(𝐰t)‖2superscriptnorm𝐠superscript𝐰𝑡∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡2\|\mathbf{g}(\mathbf{w}^{t})-\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{t})\|^{2} is bounded by σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. Equation (43) indicates that the algorithm is expected to converge when T→+∞→𝑇T\rightarrow+\infty.

For the sake of convenience, we denote the following:

𝒥=2​Gf​LT+2​2​L​GfT​σ+d​G​B,𝒥2subscript𝐺𝑓𝐿𝑇22𝐿subscript𝐺𝑓𝑇𝜎𝑑𝐺𝐵\mathcal{J}=\frac{2G_{f}L}{T}+\frac{2\sqrt{2LG_{f}}}{\sqrt{T}}\sigma+\sqrt{d}G\sqrt{B}, (47)

then from (43) we get

𝔼t∼(Unif​[T])​[‖∇F​(𝐰t)‖2]≤𝒥.subscript𝔼similar-to𝑡Unifdelimited-[]𝑇delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡2𝒥\mathbb{E}_{t\sim(\mbox{Unif}[T])}[\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{t})\|^{2}]\leq\mathcal{J}. (48)

On the other hand, for some τ>0𝜏0\tau>0, Markov’s inequality states that

Pr⁡{X≤τ​𝔼​[X]}≥1−1τ.probability𝑋𝜏𝔼delimited-[]𝑋11𝜏\Pr\{X\leq\tau\mathbb{E}[X]\}\geq 1-\frac{1}{\tau}. (49)

From (48) and (49), we obtain

Pr⁡{‖∇F​(𝐰t)‖2≤τ​𝒥}≥1−1τ,probabilitysuperscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝐰𝑡2𝜏𝒥11𝜏\Pr\{\|\nabla F(\mathbf{w}^{t})\|^{2}\leq\tau\mathcal{J}\}\geq 1-\frac{1}{\tau}, (50)

and citing the proof of B-SGD in [26]. Theorem 1 is proved. 333Following the instructions in [26], we can derive the exact number of iterations performed by SLQBM-FL to achieve an (θ,Λ)𝜃Λ(\theta,\Lambda)-solution as follows: (L​Gf​σ+L2​Gf2​σ2+θ​Λ​L2​Gf2θ​Λ)2,superscript𝐿subscript𝐺𝑓𝜎superscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑓2superscript𝜎2𝜃Λsuperscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑓2𝜃Λ2\bigg{(}\frac{LG_{f}\sigma+\sqrt{L^{2}G_{f}^{2}\sigma^{2}+\theta\Lambda L^{2}G_{f}^{2}}}{\theta\Lambda}\bigg{)}^{2}, which is simplified as: 𝒪​(1θ​Λ+σ2θ2​Λ2).𝒪1𝜃Λsuperscript𝜎2superscript𝜃2superscriptΛ2\mathcal{O}\bigg{(}\frac{1}{\theta\Lambda}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\theta^{2}\Lambda^{2}}\bigg{)}. ∎

Consequently, we obtain the following result:

4​G2​d​n​p​(1−p)K​(q−1)2≤B≤4​G2​d​(1+n​p​(1−p))K​(q−1)2.4superscript𝐺2𝑑𝑛𝑝1𝑝𝐾superscript𝑞12𝐵4superscript𝐺2𝑑1𝑛𝑝1𝑝𝐾superscript𝑞12\displaystyle\frac{4G^{2}dnp(1-p)}{K(q-1)^{2}}\leq B\leq\frac{4G^{2}d\big{(}1+np(1-p)\big{)}}{K(q-1)^{2}}.

Appendix H Proof of Theorem 5

The expressions which contain p𝑝p and appear in the terminators of the terms in Eq. (12) are as follows:

p2+(1−p)2,superscript𝑝2superscript1𝑝2\displaystyle p^{2}+(1-p)^{2},

These expressions monotonically increase with respect to p𝑝p for p∈[1/2,1)𝑝121p\in[1/2,1). Conversely, the expressions which contain p𝑝p and appear in the denominators of the terms in Eq. (12) are the powers of p​(1−p)𝑝1𝑝p(1-p) with non-negative exponents, where p​(1−p)𝑝1𝑝p(1-p) monotonically decreases with respect to p𝑝p for p∈[1/2,1)𝑝121p\in[1/2,1). Therefore, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon monotonically increases with respect to p𝑝p for p∈[1/2,1)𝑝121p\in[1/2,1).

We consider an arbitrary optimal solution (q∗,n∗,p∗,Pk∗)superscript𝑞superscript𝑛superscript𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘(q^{*},n^{*},p^{*},P_{k}^{*}) of (Φ2)subscriptΦ2(\Phi_{2}). Recall that the optimal objective values of problems (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}) and (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) are equal and each feasible solution of (Φ2subscriptΦ2\Phi_{2}) is also a feasible solution of (Φ1subscriptΦ1\Phi_{1}).
